subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 27 March 2020: Stocks fade this week’s rally; House passes bill
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

27 March 2020: Stocks fade this week’s rally; House passes bill

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: US House passes stimulus bill; UK’s Johnson tests positive; BoC emergency rate cut and credit facility; Uni of Michigan survey posts a cycle record drop.
  • COMING UP: Data: EZ Consumer Confidence, German CPI (Prelim).

MARKET WRAP

Stocks pared some of their recent strength to end the week, although came off lows after the House passed the USD 2.2trln stimulus bill, before reversing lower again into the close. While stimulus efforts in the past week have supported the, on a historical basis, extraordinary rally, it has come in the context of even more extraordinary losses – many are recognising the gains as a “bear market rally” / “bull trap”. Barclays’ strategists highlight the two uncertainties facing investors, how long the economic quarantine will be required and the resulting damage, which it believes keeps medium-term risks skewed to the downside. The decline in risk appetite supported the bid in government debt as the TPLEX bull-steepened, supported the Fed’s continued asset purchases. The dollar continued lower after one of its worst ever weeks - hats to Federal Reserve efforts to ease funding pressures (the 3-month Term repo operation saw zero bids on Friday). Oil prices continued to move lower amid the bleak outlook and no signs of Russia / Saudi cooperation.

CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 588,959, DEATHS 26,928, RECOVERED 132,440.

Figures provided as of Friday (via worldometer website) against Thursday:

  • US total cases 100,037 (prev. 85,435), death toll 1,536 (prev. 1,295).
  • ITALY total cases 86,498 (prev. 80,589), death toll 9,134 (prev. 8,215).
  • CHINA total cases 81,340 (prev. 81,285), death toll 3,292 (prev. 3,287).
  • SPAIN total cases 64,059 (prev. 57,786), death toll 4,934 (prev. 4,365).
  • GERMANY total cases 50,178 (prev. 43,938), death toll 338 (prev. 267).
  • FRANCE total cases 32,964 (prev. 29,155), death toll 1,995 (prev. 1,696).
  • UK total cases 14,543 (prev. 11,658), death toll 759 (prev. 578).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 12,928 (prev. 11,811), death toll 231 (prev. 192).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 9,332 (prev. 9,241), death toll 139 (prev. 131).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 8,603 (prev. 7,431), death toll 546 (prev. 434).
  • CANADA total cases 4,610 (prev. 4,043), death toll 53 (prev. 39).

Note figures are provided via worldometers thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: The House passed the USD 2.2trln stimulus bill, sending the bill to President Trump to sign off on. Trump said he would sign off on the bill immediately on Friday.

CHINA / US: Chinese President Xi, in a call with US President Trump, noted that China is willing to enhance macroeconomic policy coordination to stabilise markets and secure growth, state TV reported, adding that China-US relations are at an important juncture. China is reportedly willing to offer support to the US regarding virus control. Trump confirmed the call, saying that both nations agreed to work closely. Trump also said earlier that the US can do another trade deal with China, but it will have to wait until after the election.

RESTRICTIONS: US President Trump said he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing; Trump also said there is "no way" that he would cancel the Republican National Convention in August, according to Fox. US VP Pence said Trump will be presented with options on opening the economy up this weekend. Elsewhere, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers have urged the Trump administration to defer all tariffs during the pandemic, for at least a 90-day period, or until the crisis has passed.

CANADA PM Trudeau announced the government will cover 75% of payroll wages, while wage subsidies to SMEs will be backdated to March 15th. Trudeau said further details on aid to SMEs will be announced “hopefully by Monday”. In a joint press conference with BoC Governor Poloz, Finance Minister Morneau said the government is ready to do whatever it takes, adding that it is providing CAD 65bln in direct support to SME's and CAD 30bln in deferred taxes. Morneau said Canada is trying to make sure that it guarantees credit to the oil and gas sector, particularly SMEs, although is still working on the details. The Finance Minister said Canada is putting out roughly 5% of GDP or more, excluding credit, adding it may need to do more; noting there is no spending cap for the government.

CENTRAL BANKS

BOC, in an emergency move, cut another 50bps of its overnight benchmark rate to 0.25%, its effective lower bound, from 0.75%, while also launching two new programmes. In fitting with other central banks, the BoC launched a Commercial Paper Purchase Program (CPPP) to help alleviate strains in the short-term funding markets and preserve a key source of funding for businesses. The Central Bank also initiated QE where it will purchase Canadian Government securities in the secondary market and start at a minimum of $5bln per week across the curve and it noted the purchases can be adjusted as conditions warrant, but it will continue until the economic recovery is “well underway”. The BoC stated it remains ready to act further if necessary, to support the Canadian economy and financial system to keep inflation on target, stressing today’s action was taken to support the financial system in its central role of providing credit in the economy, and to lay the foundation for the economy’s return to normalcy. Note, this latest move is the third consecutive 50bp cut this month, following its scheduled announcement on March 4th and the emergency announcement March 13th. The press conference followed with Governor Poloz who, in fitting with the statement, stressed that the move was to restore the function of financial markets rather than traditional monetary stimulus. Poloz reiterated that negative rates are a part of the Bank’s toolkit, although he does not see rates going lower than the current level, however he noted theoretically it could be lowered to -0.5%, although the governor stressed  the significant negative effects on the financial system seen from other nations with NIRP and the bank is not contemplating using it. On QE, the Governor added the BoC will announce a true QE programme with a set of objectives when it is implemented and it is currently seeking to restore market function, while reiterating the statement that they will purchase bonds for as long as necessary. RBC highlight that if the purchases continue at the minimum rate of $5blnI for half a year, the size of the BoC’s balance sheet would more than double. In regards to the CPPP, Poloz stated the commercial paper market is effectively frozen and the bank wants to ensure that credit is available, hence the initiation of the CPPP facility. RBC believe that the banks next step if needed would be to increase the pace of asset purchases and “potentially broaden their scope”. This could mean “mean buying more GoC securities or ramping up CMB purchases to more QE-like levels. We also wouldn't rule out more substantial purchases of provincial and corporate securities to address wider spreads in those markets, if needed.”, the Canadian Bank writes. RBC conclude that today’s policy announcement looks appropriate at this stage, but it is impossible to rule out the need to do more given the current market conditions.

FED FACILITIES: US banks had USD 50.8bln of outstanding loans via the Discount Window, as of Wednesday (vs USD 28.2bln last week), according to Fed data. This will be encouraging to the Fed after it has made efforts to incentivize and destigmatize the facility. Elsewhere, the overnight repo operation saw continued minimal demand and its 3-month Term operations saw zero bids. The lack of demand for cash was once again exhibited in the high take-up in the reverse repo operation, which received USD 210bln in bids across 43 bidders – note that demand has been ramping up in recent sessions.

ECB said that banks should not pay dividends until at least October 2020. French Finance Minister Le Maire later said the government will not guarantee loans for companies that pay dividends.

REST OF WORLD

EUROPEAN STIMULUS: EU leaders have given finance ministers two weeks to sort out technical details of the bailout fund credit lines for the Eurozone to fight the crisis. This follows reports from the northern states that they opposed a common debt issuance (coronabonds) as a measure to best combat the virus; conversely, states such as Italy, with already strained fiscal budgets, have come out in support of joint issuance.

UK PM JOHNSON HAS TESTED POSITIVE FOR CORONA VIRUS. He has mild symptoms and will self-isolate in Downing Street. Johnson will still be in charge of the government's handling of the crisis. The announcement did cause some downside in Cable, moving from circa 1.2280 to 1.2240 before subsequently extending to the downside. Health Minister Hancock also tested positive. It was reported that other Cabinet members, such as Chancellor Sunak, may have to self-isolate after being in contact, although a Treasury source said the Chancellor was not doing such.

FRENCH PRESIDENT MACRON said he and US President Trump are preparing "a strong new initiative" with other nations, which will be unveiled in the coming days. Elsewhere, France announced it was extending the lockdown for another two weeks until April 15th.

ITALY may require new stimulus worth EUR 30bln, according to Il Sole; note on Thursday reports noted that Italian PM Conte is aiming for a new stimulus package worth in excess of EUR 25bln.

DATA

PERSONAL INCOME & SPENDING (FEB): Given the data is for February it could be deemed rather stale as it was taken before the coronavirus took its toll on the US economy. Nonetheless, Personal income rose 0.6% maintaining the prior pace, which was above expectations for a 0.4% read, while consumption was in line with expectations and continued to rise at 0.2%. Pantheon Macroeconomics highlights the rise in income was boosted by the one-time farm subsidy payments while “regular private sector wages and salaries rose by a solid 0.5%”. The consultancy notes the next two months will be very different and that Q1 spending was on course for a 1.6% increase annually, although “the 5% month-to-month drop we expect to see in March, capturing the initial collapse in spending on discretionary goods and services, suggests spending for the quarter will plunge at a 5-1/2% rate. And Q2 will be much worse.” Core PCE Y/Y rose 1.8% from 1.7%, 0.1% above expectations and the highest since August, while the MM figure maintained its 0.2% pace, in line with expectations. Non-core PCE maintained a 1.8% rise Y/Y and 0.1% pace M/M. Pantheon Macroeconomics, in reference to the core reading, expects the gains will not last but still expects a small M/M increase in March, although expects it to fall in April and May as the financial services component drops sharply, which the consultancy notes lags the stock market. Looking ahead, PM says in July the Y/Y rate will “likely be below 1.0% or less”.

UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN FINAL (MARCH): Headline sentiment came in at 89.1, worse than the expected fall to 90 from 95.9; the sharpest drop since October 2008. Conditions fell to 103.7 from 112.5 and expectations fell to 79.7 from 85.3. All three metrics were the lowest since October 2016. The inflation expectations ticked down slightly to 2.2% from 2.3%, for both the 1-year and 5-year prints. “The economics of fear are now in plain sight”, writes Oxford Economics, which highlights that the fall is a huge understatement as the survey was conducted prior to March 11th, before coronavirus responses instructed further lockdowns across the US bringing the economy to a halt. On the employment front, OxEco highlight “The share of respondents expecting more unemployment over the next year rose from 23% in February to 39%; that share is likely to go much higher.”

CRUDE

SETTLEMENT: WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 1.09 LOWER AT USD 21.51/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLED USD 0.70 LOWER AT USD 27.95/BBL.

OIL PRICES CAME UNDER PRESSURE AGAIN TO END THE WEEK, alongside a decline in equities, as the outlook remains dismal for the energy complex. There are little fundamental reasons to get long for many participants as global growth and oil demand faces a cliff edge. Meanwhile, Russia and Saudi remain in a price war. Saudi’s Energy Ministry said there have been no contact between Saudi and Russia over increasing the number of OPEC+ countries, no discussion of a joint agreement to balance oil markets. The comments followed on from earlier remarks by the Algerian Oil Minister, who called for an extraordinary OPEC panel meeting; the Russian Deputy Energy Minister also said that OPEC+ members remain in close contact. The Russian official elsewhere said that oil production in the US could fall by 1.5mln BPD in 2020 if oil prices are between USD 30-35/bbl; later adding that if prices remain around USD 25/bbl for two to three years, big problems will occur. Meanwhile, Unipec is the latest to announce it would not be lifting any additional Saudi crude in April due to raised shipping costs. The latest Baker Hughes US rig count (w/e 27th March): Oil -40 at 624, Nat Gas -4 at 102, Total -44 at 728; marking the largest drop in oil rigs since 2015.

FIXED INCOME

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 17 TICKS HIGHER AT 138-08+.

THE TPLEX BULL FLATTENED amid a decline in risk assets and active Fed operations. The bid gained steam as European trade commenced while equities trundled lower. One desk highlights the lower volumes, which had previously been swamped by short covering, hedging and spread unwinds, is making the Fed’s asset purchases felt more acutely in the tape action. Furthermore, the Fed’s aggressive liquidity options have drastically cut the dollar funding pressures, where repo operations continue to see minimal take-up, with Dealers taking advantage of the reverse repo operation as yields in front-end Bills flirt with negative territory, seeing yield-thirsty participants move further out the curve. By settlement, 30s -8bps at 1.316%, 10s -7.5bps at 0.733%, 2s -2bps at 0.254%.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -3.33% at 2543, NDX -3.91% at 7588, DJIA -4.06% at 21,637

SECTORS: Energy -6.93%, Technology -4.61%, Industrials -4.33%, Communication Svs -4.09%, Materials -3.81%, Cons Disc -3.37%, Financials -3.31%, Health -2.41%, Cons Stpl -0.72%, Real Estate -0.07%, Utilities +0.52%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Defensives the relative outperformers with Utilities (XLU), Consumer Staples (XLP) and Real Estate marginally lower in comparison, while Health Care (XLV) followed. XLP aided as consumers continue to stockpile staple goods and cleaning supplies (CLX), while Pepsi (PEP) managed to close flat despite a double upgrade to Outperform from Credit Suisse, Colgate Palmolive (CL) and Procter & Gamble (PG) were upgraded to Buy from Hold at Stifel seeing solid gains. Energy (XLE) the underperforming sector falling roughly 7% amid weaker oil prices as there still seems to be no end in sight for the Russia/Saudi pricing war as comments from Saudi Arabia stated there is no discussion regarding joint output cuts, nor about increasing the size of OPEC+.  Elsewhere, cruise liners were hit after WSJ reported  big cruise liners will not qualify for aid under the US stimulus package after a last minute legislative change has shut the companies out of the coronavirus bill as the Democrats and Labor had opposed aid to the offshore based cruise industry. While Carnival (CCL) is reportedly looking for up to USD 7bln in new debt. Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) announced it is furloughing 41k workers, while big banks (XLF, BAC, WFC, DB, JPM, GS, MS) are reportedly reassuring staff and postponing decisions about potential job cuts as they are worried about being unprepared if business suddenly picks up. L Brands (LB) announce it is to suspend its dividend from Q2 while closing its stores until further notice. Apple (AAPL) is reportedly working with the White House to create an app which will provide CDC guidance to users. Lululemon (LULU) fell over 5% despite tom and bottom-line beats, while reporting comparable store sales +9%, however, it did withdraw its guidance. United Tech (UTX) and Raytheon (RTN) had its deal approved by the DoJ, subject to conditions that it sells all assets related to military airborne radios, GPS systems and its optical systems businesses. United Airlines (UAL) states it will not go ahead with involuntary furloughs or pay cuts in the US before September 30th although if the recovery is as slow as it fears, its airline and workforce will have to be smaller. UAL stated it doesn’t expect travel demand to snap back for some time and expects demand to remain suppressed perhaps into next year. The airline also expects load factors to fall into the teens or single digits even with 60% less capacity. Tesla (TSLA) is to reportedly cut staff at its battery plant in Nevada by 75% amid COVID-19. Gap (GPS) announced it has drawn down USD 500mln, 100% of its revolving credit facility, and it is deferring the payment dates for its Q1 dividend while suspending any quarterly dividends for the remainder of FY20 and withdrawing guidance.

FOREX

WEEKLY FX WRAP: YEN GATHERS MORE MOMENTUM AMIDST RISK-OFF FRIDAY MOVES

JPY: 108.00 held for a while, but the Yen subsequently posted fresh highs for the week above the round number on safe-haven positioning following a breach of the 200 DMA in Usd/Jpy (108.29) and an extended retreat from circa 111.70. Japan is far from immune in terms of the global nCoV pandemic and the BoJ has stepped up stimulus via increased purchases of securities, while the Government has approved a supplementary budget, but contagion is arguably worse elsewhere. Hence, the Yen has reasserted its credentials as the go to currency for investors and speculators paring back risk exposure or liquidating, especially as month, quarter and fy end looms next Tuesday. In contrast, the Dollar has handed back more gains alongside dissipating stress in credit and diminishing demand for liquidity/funding purposes, with the DXY pulling back further from ytd peaks through 100.000 and all the way down under Fib support around 98.840 before arresting the slide.

GBP: A distinctly better week for the Pound, albeit after Cable swooned towards 1985 lows again and Eur/Gbp traded close to 0.9400 at one stage, as Sterling benefits from more short covering on top of the aforementioned Greenback retracement. Indeed, Cable managed to form a series of higher lows throughout the week from circa 1.1450 to eventually fill a key technical retracement gap (50% Fib of fall from 1.3200 to 1.1412) before topping out and recoiling to sub-1.2200 levels when news broke that UK PM Johnson has contracted the coronavirus, and then rebounding beyond 1.2400 when the Buck came under pressure again and stops were triggered through a series of upside tech levels (including the 21 DMA). For the record, normally top tier data in the form of CPI and retail sales (at the new earlier 7.00GMT ONS release time) was largely shrugged off, along with preliminary PMIs even though the surveys were bleak overall and the BoE flagged their importance after previously playing down the role of the findings in terms of policy deliberations. On that note, the scheduled March MPC meeting passed without much fanfare as rates and APF were left as is following the 2 emergency eases and new QE tranche earlier this month.

USD: Aside from losing the tag of cash king due in no small part to the Fed expanding and enhancing swap lines, the Dollar was undermined by a staggering jump in US initial claims that completely blitzed the prior all time apex, at almost 3.3 mn. Moreover, there is a reasonable and rational thesis, rather than conspiratorial, the number could have been even higher if all applications lodged were processed instead of agency staff ploughing through as many as possible due to the overload.

EUR: Although Italy has become the new COVID-19 epicentre and Spain’s confirmed case/fatality count seems to be catching up, the single currency remains on track to net gains vs the Buck within a wide 1.1086-1.0638 range. However, the single currency has weakened independently, between 0.8940-0.9390 against the Pound and 1.0653-1.0531 vs the Franc amidst uncertainty and ongoing bickering over a coordinated fiscal response to the virus from Eurozone Governments, including the use of OMTs to supplement ECB efforts like the QE envelope and PEPP that kicked in this week.

CHF: Swiss bank sight deposits continue to rise, while the Government and SNB have injected more forms of liquidity and credit, but the even more highly valued Franc is still appreciating with Usd/Chf eyeing a new base near 0.9555 compared to almost 0.9900 at the other end of the spectrum.

AUD/NZD/CAD: Very volatile weeks and a somewhat contrasting final trading session for the non-US Dollars, as the Antipodes mostly danced to the risk sentiment tune that changed tone several times, though also moved in lock-step with other G10 peers inversely to their US counterpart. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are ending near or at fresh peaks around 0.6134 and 0.6029 respectively, but Usd/Cad has bounced from sub-1.4000 in wake of the BoC’s 3rd impromptu 50 bp rate cut that came with QE and a Fed-style commercial paper buying vehicle given that conventional policy has now reached the lower bound. Nevertheless, Governor Poloz did not rule out NIRP altogether and the Loonie is still off worst levels vs its US rival circa 1.4560.

SCANDI/EM: Also victims and sometimes criminals over the course of yet another manic, frantic and often fickle 5 days in FX land, but the Scandi Crowns have fared well on technical grounds irrespective of crude’s latest capitulation that normally undermines the Nok in particular, and the spectre of Norges Bank intervention continues to impact. Conversely, the Rub has been hit hard by Brent’s sharp retreat from recent recovery highs and no sign of Russia or Saudi Arabia settling the dispute over prices and share of the dwindling spoils. Meanwhile, the spread of nCoV is taking an increasing and wider toll to the extent that the BCB may now be on the brink of buying bonds and SA is in grave danger of losing its last non-junk ratings standing when Moody’s delivers its long awaited review.

Weekly FX Wrap: Yen gathers more momentum amidst risk-off Friday moves

USD 

Aside from losing the tag of cash king due in no small part to the Fed expanding and enhancing swap lines, the Dollar was undermined by a staggering jump in US initial claims that completely blitzed the prior all time apex, at almost 3.3 mn. Moreover, there is a reasonable and rational thesis, rather than conspiratorial, the number could have been even higher if all applications lodged were processed instead of agency staff ploughing through as many as possible due to the overload.

EUR

Although Italy has become the new COVID-19 epicentre and Spain’s confirmed case/fatality count seems to be catching up, the single currency remains on track to net gains vs the Buck within a wide 1.1086-1.0638 range. However, the single currency has weakened independently, between 0.8940-0.9390 against the Pound and 1.0653-1.0531 vs the Franc amidst uncertainty and ongoing bickering over a coordinated fiscal response to the virus from Eurozone Governments, including the use of OMTs to supplement ECB efforts like the QE envelope and PEPP that kicked in this week.

CHF

Swiss bank sight deposits continue to rise, while the Government and SNB have injected more forms of liquidity and credit, but the even more highly valued Franc is still appreciating with Usd/Chf eyeing a new base near 0.9555 compared to almost 0.9900 at the other end of the spectrum.

AUD/NZD/CAD 

Very volatile weeks and a somewhat contrasting final trading session for the non-US Dollars, as the Antipodes mostly danced to the risk sentiment tune that changed tone several times, though also moved in lock-step with other G10 peers inversely to their US counterpart. Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are ending near or at fresh peaks around 0.6134 and 0.6029 respectively, but Usd/Cad has bounced from sub-1.4000 in wake of the BoC’s 3rd impromptu 50 bp rate cut that came with QE and a Fed-style commercial paper buying vehicle given that conventional policy has now reached the lower bound. Nevertheless, Governor Poloz did not rule out NIRP altogether and the Loonie is still off worst levels vs its US rival circa 1.4560.

SCANDI/EM

Also victims and sometimes criminals over the course of yet another manic, frantic and often fickle 5 days in FX land, but the Scandi Crowns have fared well on technical grounds irrespective of crude’s latest capitulation that normally undermines the Nok in particular, and the spectre of Norges Bank intervention continues to impact. Conversely, the Rub has been hit hard by Brent’s sharp retreat from recent recovery highs and no sign of Russia or Saudi Arabia settling the dispute over prices and share of the dwindling spoils. Meanwhile, the spread of nCoV is taking an increasing and wider toll to the extent that the BCB may now be on the brink of buying bonds and SA is in grave danger of losing its last non-junk ratings standing when Moody’s delivers its long awaited review.

The sector also benefiting from gains in Pepsi (PEP) & Kroger (KR) who are among SPX outperformers, after the former was double upgraded to Outperform at Credit Suisse. Colgate Palmolive (CL) and Procter & Gamble (PG) also performing well following upgrades to Buy from Hold at Stifel. content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

27th March 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1300GMT/0900CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

  • Of note for Cruise operators (CCL, RCL, NCLH), WSJ reported big cruise liners will not qualify for aid under the US stimulus package after a last minute legislative change has shut the companies out of the coronavirus bill as the Democrats and Labor had opposed aid to offshore based cruise industry.
  • Of note for Semiconductors/Huawei Suppliers (SOX, MU, WDC, OCLR, LITE, ACIA), Senior Trump administration officials agreed to restrict the global supply of chips to Huawei, according to people familiar with the matter, as the White House increases its criticism of China in regards to the Coronavirus. Elsewhere, UBS upgraded Semiconductor Equipment names (AMAT, KLAC, LRCX, TXN), it believes a 20% earnings cut is now priced into the stocks, adding that suggests staying negative would be “fighting an uphill battle”.
  • Of note for Banking names (JPM, C, MS, GS, WFC, BAC, DB), big banks are reportedly reassuring staff and postponing decisions about potential job cuts as they are worried about being unprepared if business suddenly picks up.

DOW JONES

  • Apple Inc. (AAPL) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) suppliers PCB denied reports they have been asked to delay production by two months in line with a launch delay for Apple’s next generation devices, according to DigiTimes. Elsewhere, it is reportedly planning to launch several Mac notebooks and desktop computer with its own custom designed ARM-based processors in 2021, according to MacRumors.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) has been upgraded to Buy from Hold at Argus, with a USD 220 PT, noting given its production developments and recent decline in share price, a Buy rating is now warranted.
  • United Technologies (UTX) and Raytheon (RTN) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) reportedly had its deal approved by the DoJ after both agreed to sell all assets related to military airborne radios, GPS systems and optical systems businesses.

NASDAQ 100

  • Facebook, Inc. (FB) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) announced it named former Deputy Treasury Secretary and US Ambassador to Germany, Robert Kimmitt, to its board of Directors as lead independent director.
  • Lululemon Athletica Inc (LULU) (Consumer Discretionary/Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) Q4 19 (USD): EPS 2.28 (exp. 2.24), Revenue 1.40bln (exp. 1.38bln). Comparable store sales +9%. Announced it is not providing FY20 guidance at this time due to uncertainties around COVID-19. 
  • Vertex Pharmaceuticals Inc (VRTX) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced it has confirmed its FY20 business outlook and the continuity of its supply chain for its Cystic Fibrosis medicines
  • Tesla (TSLA) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) – Piper Sandler maintained its overweight rating on the name, although lowered its PT to USD 820 from USD 928, stating the market dislocation is an opportunity to buy the EV maker. Elsewhere, the EV maker is reportedly planning to cut staff on site at its Nevada battery plant by roughly 75% amid COVID-19, according to reports citing the local country manager. Dozens of its workers reportedly had to continue work at factories this week to finish the final batches of cars despite officials confirming TSLA halted production on March 23rd, according to The Verge.

S&P 500

  • Apache Corporation (APA) (Energy/Oil & Gas Exploration & Production) announced it has ample liquidity and a very manageable bond maturity profile for the next five years after S&P cut its credit rating to BB+ from BBB.
  • Conagra Brands (CAG) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) announced it will be paying production and distribution employees in US, Mexico and Canada a cash bonus of USD 250 for part time workers, and USD 500 for full time workers.
  • Gap Inc. (GPS) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel Retail) announced it has drawn down USD 500mln, 100% of its revolving credit facility, and it is deferring the payment dates for its Q1 dividend while suspending any quarterly dividends for the remainder of FY20 and withdrawing FY20 guidance.
  • General Mills (GIS) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) announced 90% of its stores in China have re-opened.
  • General Motors (GM) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) announced production at its North American plants will remain halted beyond March 30th, its original production restart date.
  • Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc (HLT) (Consumer Discretionary/Hotels, Resorts & Cruise Lines) announced its CEO is forgoing his salary for FY20 and the executive committee will have pay cut in half, while also announcing it is eliminating CapEx and suspending its share repurchase programme and payment of dividends.
  • Macerich (MAC) (Real Estate/Retail REITs) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance.
  • Molson Coors Brewing Company (TAP) (Consumer Staples/Brewers) announced it has withdrawn its its FY20 guidance due to uncertainty around COVID-19.
  • Morgan Stanley (MS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) reportedly received regulatory approval to take a majority stake in Morgan Stanley Huaxin Securities in China, according to people familiar with the matter.

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 27th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment remains subdued, in a turnaround from yesterday, as focus turns from stimulus measures back to rising virus case counts
  • Spain's coronavirus cases increase to 64059 from 56188; deaths at 4858 from 4089
  • US confirmed cases stand at 81,378 - highest in the world, according to a Reuters calculation
  • US House set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials
  • In FX, the USD is firmer as the index fights back from a week which has featured hefty losses; though the 100.0 mark remains elusive
  • UK PM Johnson has tested positive for the virus, reports which caused immediate and ongoing downside for GBP
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Personal Income, University of Michigan (Final) & PCE Price Index

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Spain's coronavirus cases increase to 64059 from 56188; deaths at 4858 from 4089. (Newswires)

UK PM Johnson has tested positive for Corona virus. He has mild symptoms and will self-isolate in Downing Street. but he will still be in charge of the government's handling of the crisis, according to BBC's Kuenssberg. (BBC)

President Macron said he and US President Trump are preparing "a strong new initiative" with other nations; to be unveiled in the coming days (Newswires)

China mainland reported 55 new virus cases (vs 67 on Thursday); total case count 81,340 as of end-26th March; 5 new deaths in the period (vs 6 reported on Thursday); no new cases in Hubei, though 5 new deaths reported                                                                                            . (Newswires) South Korea total covid-19 case count 91 today, taking the total to 9,332, according to KCDC. (Newswires)

US confirmed cases stand at 81,378 - highest in the world, according to a Reuters calculation. (Newswires) NOTE: This data is a tally by Reuters; official data earlier showed the covid case count rise to 68,440 on Thursday (from  54,453), while the official death toll was up to 994 from 737

US House set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials. The Bill may not be able to pass via voice vote, and it was unclear on the timings of the next step, like a roll-call vote, the House Majority Leader's office said. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing. US VP Pence says President Trump will be presented with options on opening the economy up this weekend. Bipartisan group of US lawmakers have urged the Trump administration to defer all tariffs during the covid pandemic, for at least a 90-day period, or until the crisis has passed. US President Trump said there is "no way" that he would cancel the Republican National Convention in August due to the virus, according to Fox (Newswires)

Japan Economy Minister said there was no need to declare a state of emergency over covid-19. (Newswires)

OECD says for each month of containment there will be a 2% loss in annual GDP growth for major economies. (Newswires)

ASIA

 

Major APAC indices initially took their cues from Wall Street, rising firmly at the open, amid optimism that policymakers will continue to roll-out stimulus measures to guard economies against covid-induced downside. However, as the European day comes into focus, the picture is mixed, as Aussie shares turned negative, and other bourses off highs. US indices finished up around 6%, with the Dow seeing its strongest three day run since 1931 and re-entering a bull-market, while the S&P had its best three-day performance since 1933. Gains were led by defensive sectors (utilities, telecoms, health care). Equities shrugged-off the highest weekly jobless claims print on record. Some desks also noted that month/quarter-end rebalancing will see 850bln of flows into equities. US equity futures opened firmer, though subsequently gave up gains, and are trading lower, albeit off worst levels. ASX 200 (-5.3%) was led lower by its heavyweight financial and mining sectors, while the Nikkei 225 (+3.8%) shrugged off a firmer JPY, with some optimism in the country emanating from Japanese Economy Minister Nishimura who stated that there was no need to declare a state of emergency over the outbreak. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) remained in positive territory and were buoyed by increased efforts from Chinese officials to stem a substantial second wave of the virus in the country, with reports yesterday noting that airport tests will be ramped up for people arriving from abroad.

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0427 vs. Exp. 7.0531 (Prev. 7.0692) (Newswires). PBoC skipped open market operations

US is moving forward with plans to limit chips to Huawei, according to the WSJ, citing sources. The proposal would require export licenses for many of the chips that are sold to Huawei that are made by US manufacturers. (WSJ) US President Trump said it looks like the US can do another trade deal with China, though it will have to wait until after the Presidential election. (Newswires) US President Trump confirmed his conversation with China President Xi and said both nations agree to work closely together on virus. (Twitter)

South Korea Consumer Sentiment Ind* (Mar) 78.4 (Prev. 96.9, Rev. 96.9). (Newswires) China Industrial Profits (Jan-Feb) declined 38.3% Y/Y (previous -3.3%)

Australia PM Morrison said government is preparing a third tranche of economic relief. (Newswires)

RBI cuts rates by 75bps to 4.4%; voted 4-2 to cut rates; reverse repo rate lowered to 4.15%. Governor Das said the move was designed to mitigate effects of the virus, revive growth and preserve financial stability. He added that the RBI's response must involve conventional and unconventional measures. Das noted that inflation was running higher than projections in January and February, and that aggregate demand may weaken, and ease inflation further due to Covid-19. Das also said projections for growth and inflation will be dependent on how Covid progresses; he noted that uncertainties in the outlook and explained that is why the MPC has refrained from providing growth and inflation forecasts. Das also announced targeted long-term repo operations, offering up to INR 1trln.

US

US banks had USD 50.8bln of outstanding loans via the discount window, as of Wednesday (vs USD 28.2bln last week), according to Fed data. (Newswires)

UK/EU

EU leaders gave finance ministers two weeks to sort out technical details of bailout fund credit lines for the Eurozone to fight the crisis. German Chancellor Merkel said that, for Germany, the ESM is the main instrument to help other European countries during the virus crisis. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi-led coalition said it intercepted and destroyed missiles fired by Yemeni Houthis, according to Saudi state news. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

A downbeat session thus far for European equities (Euro Stoxx 50 -3.3%) as the bourses look set to snap its three-day rally heading into another risky virus-focused weekend. US equity futures follow suit from Europe with losses currently tallying to around 2% per index – with eyes State-side on the virus bill which is poised to make its passage through the House later today. Back to Europe, UK’s FTSE 100 (-3.9%) underperforms the region with a number of its stocks at the foot of the Stoxx 600 index as caution arises from the prospect of delayed UK/EU FTA negotiations, despite the already-tight schedule – whilst housing and banks names also see headwinds from the UK govt calling for the halt of home purchases/sales.  Meanwhile, Italy’s FTSE MIB (-2.3%) continues to feel some support from the ECB dismissing the 33% issuer limit for its emergency program purchases. European sectors reside largely in the red but reflect risk aversion, whilst underperformance is seen in the Energy sector on account of the downside in Brent prices. The sector breakdown meanwhile sees Travel & Leisure pressured on the ongoing virus-induced demand woes for the sector. Looking at individual movers, ProsiebentSat1 (+7.0%) sees upside amid the immediate resignation of its CEO, and with potential tailwinds from work-from-home flows. LafargeHolcim (-3.5%) and Safran (-2.3%) shares are pressured after the Cos withdrew their respective FY targets.

FX

USD - The Greenback has regained an element of composure after yesterday’s slide and extended losses across the board, with some analysts suggesting that the DXY eventually found technical respite in the form of Fib support around 98.840 and others noting that the index is correlating quite well with moves in the VIX. Both theories appear credible and are backed up by price developments given the DXY’s subsequent recovery to 99.500+ and the so called fear gauge climbing to 67 from around 61 at settlement on Thursday. Certainly, traditional fundamentals and data do not seem to be driving sentiment or direction as the focus remains firmly on COVID-19 amidst the backdrop of swings in global stock markets and risk assets vs safe-havens.

JPY/GBP/AUD - Bucking the overall trend, or resisting the broad Dollar revival to be more precise, as the Yen retains its renowned safe-haven allure above 109.00, while Sterling appears to have formed another higher platform on the 1.2100 handle to probe above 1.2300 and match a key chart resistance level (50% retracement of reversal from 1.3200 to 1.1412), albeit with the aid of Eur/Gbp tailwinds as the cross recoils from almost 0.9100 to sub-0.9000, with month/quarter end positioning cited on top of possible official Pound buying interest. Elsewhere, the Aussie is holding up relatively well and again month-end demand has been touted alongside exporter bids, leverage stops and momentum accounts joining the break of 0.6100 to the overnight highs.

CAD/EUR/NZD/CHF - The Loonie is underperforming after failing to sustain momentum through 1.4000 and record low Canadian crude prices may be weighing along with contagion from the coronavirus after the huge spike in US weekly claims that is expected to be evident in domestic data given reports that 500k people applied for benefits last week. Similarly, the Euro topped out ahead of 1.1100 and is waning on the ongoing spread of pandemic cases and fatalities across the common currency community, with particular focus on Italy and Spain. However, decent option expiries at the 1.1000 strike (1 bn) may provide a buffer for Eur/Usd. In contrast, the Franc and Kiwi are both rangebound within 0.9645-0.9587 and 0.6126-0.5921 respective bands.

EM - Broad retracements as the Usd consolidates off its lows, but the Zar also conceding ground in the run up to Moody’s SA ratings review that could well see the sovereign lose its last non-junk standing. Note also, the Rand has been ruffled by the first COVID-19 deaths as the country starts a 3 week lockdown.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-        EUR/USD: 1.0900 (1BLN), 1.0915-20 (480M), 1.0950 (375M), 1.1000 (1.1BLN), 1.1025 (600M), 1.1150 (570M)

-        USD/JPY: 108.00 (250M), 108.35 (360M), 109.50-60 (1BLN), 110.00 (1.4BLN), 110.20-30 (900M)

-        EUR/JPY: 120.85 (1.8BLN)

Riksbank business survey notes that the COVID-19 pandemic has had a substantial effect on large companies and the situation has deteriorated extremely rapidly. Companies are affected on three different fronts: through disruptions to production, reduced demand and financing difficulties. (Riksbank)

FIXED

Buying has been much more measured and gradual, but after a period of consolidation and mild retracement the core Eurozone bond has crept closer to the next upside chart target at 172.47 (March 17 peak), at 172.43 so far, and the steady incline is dragging Gilts and USTs higher, as stocks hand back more of Thursday’s gains. Pre-weekend positioning that often favours safe-havens is also at play, although month/Q1 end rebalancing models have been signalling hefty equity requirements for asset portfolios

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures see divergence, with outperformance seen in the former after yesterday’s -7.7% settlement, whilst ICE Brent closed lower by around 4% yesterday. Today’s narrowing in spread seems to be more of a consolidation of the prior session’s widening – which emanated from reports that the US Department of Energy suspended its SPR refill after the DoE failed to secure funding. ING notes that “The US government was keen to fill up the SPR in a bid to help domestic producers, however, news of the suspension has weighed heavily on WT.” Meanwhile, on the OPEC front, the Algerian Oil minister has called for an extraordinary meeting of the OPEC economic panel to assess current conditions and immediate prospects of the oil market, whilst Russia noted that its oil output could decline by 1.5mln BPD this year if prices meander around USD 30-35/bbl – levels above current oil prices, although communication with OPEC+ members remain. Desks note that production cuts needed to counter the sharp decline in demand would be too much for OPEC+ producers to cope with. WTI futures pulled back from ~USD 23/bbl whilst its Brent counterpart treads water just under USD 26/bbl. Elsewhere, spot gold remains lacklustre above USD 1600/oz as the Dollar recoups some of yesterday’s losses. Copper meanwhile remained largely uneventful around USD 2.2/lb following a mixed APAC session.

Algerian Oil Minister has called for an extraordinary meeting of the OPEC economic panel in order to asses current conditions and immediate prospects for the oil market; requests meetign is held no later than April 10th. (Newswires)

subject: Newsquawk EU Mid Session: Stocks set to snap winning streak as weekend risk looms - 27th March 2020

China are reportedly set to raise its fiscal deficit ratio, according to CCTV
Chinese Politburo says that economic development, particularly in supply chains is facing new challenges as COVID-19 spreads
content:
• Will step up macro policy adjustments and enforcement.
  • Will guide interest rates lower and keep liquidity reasonably ample

ECB says banks should be prudent when it comes to deciding about dividends, should avoid a situation where capital needs would arise

BAML:  USD 234.6bln record inflow into cash for the week to Wednesday, and a record USD 109bln in redemption from bond funds. Outflows from equity funds were USD 26.2bln. Gov't bonds first outflow for 9-weeks, USD 3.7bln

subject: Tata Motors - to move their passenger vehicles into a separate unit
Airbus (AIR FP) - have been placed on credit watch 'Negative' from 'Stable' at S&P
Gilts and Short Sterling futures relatively lethargic
content: UK bonds appear somewhat caught between stalls in early Liffe trade after correcting higher in line with runaway Bunds, but running in to offers ahead of nearest technical resistance again and retreating to a 135.83 vs yesterday’s 135.93 close and 136.23 at best. Meanwhile, STIR contracts are marginally mixed with the strip slightly steeper, though lacking in real conviction and clear direction following Thursday’s scheduled BoE policy announcements and minutes of the prior emergency meeting that did not offer anything new in terms of forward guidance. However, Gilts still seem wary about the funding and DMO issuance implications of the vast fiscal support measures rolled out to counter the effects of nCoV.

subject: Riksbank business survey notes that the COVID-19 pandemic has had a substantial effect on large companies and the situation has deteriorated extremely rapidly
content:
• Companies are affected on three different fronts: through disruptions to production, reduced demand and financing difficulties. 
  • This is the conclusion from the interviews the Riksbank held with major companies in recent weeks.
  • Many say that more needs to be done for especially vulnerable sectors.
  • Link to release here
analysis_details: • Representatives of 31 companies with a total of around 230,000 employees in Sweden were interviewed during the period 12 to 28 February. On 4 to 6 March, telephone interviews were held with more than 50 companies in the industrial, retail and service sectors, and on 16 to 19 March,

subject: Japan are favouring a domestically-created design for its next-gen fighter, after rejecting overseas plans, according to sources; contract said to be worth USD 40bln
Russia says that oil production in the US could fall by 1.5mln bpd in 2020 if oil prices are at USD 30-35bbl, according to the Russian Deputy Energy Minister via Interfax
Japanese PM Abe is to hold a news conference on Saturday evening, according to Jiji
analysis_details: • earlier reports noted that Japanese Economic MInister Nishimura will set up panel to consider the emergency declaration and that PM Abe instructed to move quickly on panel, but added that they are not thinking about declaring an emergency now

subject: European equity movers this morning: Airbus (AIR FP) +2.7%, Sanofi (SAN FP) +2.1%, Publicis (PUB FP) -0.3%, Hammerson (HMSO LN) -7.2%, Barratt Development (BDEV LN) -6.5%, RBS (RBS LN) -6.3%, Berkeley (BKG) -6.1%, Barclays (BARC LN) -6%
Bunds: accelerated gains in fast market conditions
content: The 10 year German benchmark has lost a bit of momentum ahead of the EU cash bourse opens, but not before blasting through the 172.00 level to post a fresh weekly high at 172.23 vs Thursday’s 171.07 close. All this after a relatively sedate overnight session that kicked off with a modest gap down to 170.95 and light follow through selling to a 170.90 low, as bulls really took charge once Monday’s session peak (171.54) was breached, but trade remains very volatile and erratic awaiting more updates on COVID-19 and measures to combat the fallout in medical, economic and fiscal terms.

subject: Royal Mail (RMG LN) - Co. continues to expect FY19 adj. operating profit (before IFRS16) of GBP 330-340mln, preserves cash board's intent not to propose a final dividend - Co. also suspends guidance
Russian Deputy Energy Minister says OPEC+ members remain in contact, according to Interfax
French Employment Minster is to ask Co's in which they have a stake not to pay a dividend amidst the virus crisis
UK DMO are seeking views on gilts for a conventional, April 1st, Gilt tender
Major FX expiry options for today's NY close

Iraq requests that all international oil Co's cut their budgets & expenses by 30% due to the oil price drop, on the condition that such cuts do not impact their production levels, Senior Iraqi Official
Additional European Equity Stories
content:
European Banking Federation: believes that listed banks should not either accrue dividend or partake in share buybacks. (Newswires)

Fraport (FRA GY) – CEO expects significant cut in 2020 air traffic even if summer is stronger than current levels. (Newswires)

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
27th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Major APAC indices initially took their cues from Wall Street, rising firmly at the open, amid optimism that policymakers will continue to roll-out stimulus measures to guard economies against covid-induced downside. However, as the European day comes into focus, the picture is mixed, as Aussie shares turned negative, and other bourses off highs. US indices finished up around 6%, with the Dow seeing its strongest three day run since 1931 and re-entering a bull-market, while the S&P had its best three-day performance since 1933. Gains were led by defensive sectors (utilities, telecoms, health care). Equities shrugged-off the highest weekly jobless claims print on record. Airlines rose as they stand to benefit from the government's virus relief package, which was the most cited reason for gains on Thursday. Some desks also noted that month/quarter-end rebalancing will see 850bln of flows into equities. US equity futures opened firmer, though have subsequently given up gains, and are trading over 1% in the red. ASX 200 (-4.6%) was led lower by its heavyweight financial and mining sectors, while the Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) shrugged off a firmer JPY, with some optimism in the country emanating from Japanese Economy Minister Nishimura who stated that there was no need to declare a state of emergency over the outbreak. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) remained in positive territory and were buoyed by increased efforts from Chinese officials to stem a substantial second wave of the virus in the country, with reports yesterday noting that airport tests will be ramped up for people arriving from abroad.

FTSE 100

Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 27th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        Major APAC bourses started the day on a firm footing but later waned off highs; ASX 200 underperformed

·        US House set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials

·        UK and EU negotiating rounds have been abandoned amid coronavirus pandemic, according to The Guardian.

·        In FX, DXY weakened further and traded on either side of 99.000, USD/JPY declined below 109.00, AUD/USD gained on further fiscal hopes

·        Looking ahead, highlights include US Personal Income, University of Michigan (Final) & PCE Price Index

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

Italy’s COVID-19 cases rose to 80,539 (prev. 74,386); death toll rises to 8,165 (prev. 7,503). Italy rejected the draft prepared for the EU Leaders' Summit on COVID-19 response, according to PM Conte's office. (Newswires)

France’s COVID-19 death toll rises to 1,696 (prev. 1,331). President Macron said he and US President Trump are preparing "a strong new initiative" with other nations; to be unveiled in the coming days (Newswires)

China mainland reported 55 new virus cases (vs 67 on Thursday); total case count 81,340 as of end-26th March; 5 new deaths in the period (vs 6 reported on Thursday); no new cases in Hubei, though 5 new deaths reported. (Newswires) South Korea total covid-19 case count 91 today, taking the total to 9,332, according to KCDC. (Newswires)

UK COVID-19 cases rose to 11,658 (prev. 9,529), death toll rises to 578 (prev. 463). NOTE: NHS changed the timings on when it reports figures. Meaning Wednesday & Thursday figures cover different time periods. March 24 (43 deaths) covers 8hr window. March 25 figure (113 deaths covers 24 hr window). (Newswires)

US confirmed cases stand at 81,378 - highest in the world, according to a Reuters calculation. (Newswires) NOTE: This data is a tally by Reuters; official data earlier showed the covid case count rise to 68,440 on Thursday (from  54,453), while the official death toll was up to 994 from 737

US House set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials. The Bill may not be able to pass via voice vote, and it was unclear on the timings of the next step, like a roll-call vote, the House Majority Leader's office said. (Newswires)

US President Trump said the administration preparing virus guidelines that would characterise countries as high-, medium- and low-risk, according to a letter. US President Trump said he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing. US VP Pence says President Trump will be presented with options on opening the economy up this weekend. Bipartisan group of US lawmakers have urged the Trump administration to defer all tariffs during the covid pandemic, for at least a 90-day period, or until the crisis has passed. US President Trump said there is "no way" that he would cancel the Republican National Convention in August due to the virus, according to Fox (Newswires)

US NIH's Fauci said guidelines will soon be set on how many days an individual must wait after recovering from COVID-19 before returning to regular life. White House Advisor Conway said G20 leaders discussed ways to try to have minimal disruption to global supply chains. (Newswires)

Japan Economy Minister said there was no need to declare a state of emergency over covid-19. (Newswires)

ASIA

Major APAC indices initially took their cues from Wall Street, rising firmly at the open, amid optimism that policymakers will continue to roll-out stimulus measures to guard economies against covid-induced downside. However, as the European day comes into focus, the picture is mixed, as Aussie shares turned negative, and other bourses off highs. US indices finished up around 6%, with the Dow seeing its strongest three day run since 1931 and re-entering a bull-market, while the S&P had its best three-day performance since 1933. Gains were led by defensive sectors (utilities, telecoms, health care). Equities shrugged-off the highest weekly jobless claims print on record. Some desks also noted that month/quarter-end rebalancing will see 850bln of flows into equities. US equity futures opened firmer, though subsequently gave up gains, and are trading lower, albeit off worst levels. ASX 200 (-4.6%) was led lower by its heavyweight financial and mining sectors, while the Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) shrugged off a firmer JPY, with some optimism in the country emanating from Japanese Economy Minister Nishimura who stated that there was no need to declare a state of emergency over the outbreak. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.0%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) remained in positive territory and were buoyed by increased efforts from Chinese officials to stem a substantial second wave of the virus in the country, with reports yesterday noting that airport tests will be ramped up for people arriving from abroad.

PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0427 vs. Exp. 7.0531 (Prev. 7.0692) (Newswires). PBoC skipped open market operations

US is moving forward with plans to limit chips to Huawei, according to the WSJ, citing sources. The proposal would require export licenses for many of the chips that are sold to Huawei that are made by US manufacturers. (WSJ) US President Trump said it looks like the US can do another trade deal with China, though it will have to wait until after the Presidential election. (Newswires) US President Trump confirmed his conversation with China President Xi and said both nations agree to work closely together on virus. (Twitter)

South Korea Consumer Sentiment Ind* (Mar) 78.4 (Prev. 96.9, Rev. 96.9). (Newswires) China Industrial Profits (Jan-Feb) declined 38.3% Y/Y (previous -3.3%)

Australia PM Morrison said government is preparing a third tranche of economic relief. (Newswires)

RBI cuts rates by 75bps to 4.4%; voted 4-2 to cut rates; reverse repo rate lowered to 4.15%. Governor Das said the move was designed to mitigate effects of the virus, revive growth and preserve financial stability. He added that the RBI's response must involve conventional and unconventional measures. Das noted that inflation was running higher than projections in January and February, and that aggregate demand may weaken, and ease inflation further due to Covid-19. Das also said projections for growth and inflation will be dependent on how Covid progresses; he noted that uncertainties in the outlook and explained that is why the MPC has refrained from providing growth and inflation forecasts. Das also announced targeted long-term repo operations, offering up to INR 1trln.

UK/EU

UK Chancellor Sunak announced support for the self-employed; will pay self-employed taxable grant of 80% of average monthly profits of the last three years. The government will be open to those with trading profits of up to GBP 50,000 annually (or GBP 2,500 per month). Chancellor Sunak wants to get the self-employed scheme up by mid-June. (Newswires)

UK and EU negotiating rounds have been abandoned amid coronavirus pandemic, with EU accusing Britain of failing to table a comprehensive legal text for them to work with, according to The Guardian. (Twitter)

EU leaders gave finance ministers two weeks to sort out technical details of bailout fund credit lines for the Eurozone to fight the crisis. German Chancellor Merkel said that, for Germany, the ESM is the main instrument to help other European countries during the virus crisis. (Newswires)

FX

The DXY started the Asia day going sideways, having relinquished the 100.00 level in US trade, amid record high jobless claims. Policymaker support has added Dollars into the system, and accordingly cross currency basis has eased, which has seen the JPY continue to advance despite a constructive risk environment, where stocks were mostly higher. USD/JPY gave up the 109.00 level and remained around session lows as European players enter the market. Risk sensitive FX are firmer, accordingly (AUD, NZD, CAD, GBP); particularly the Aussie, which vaulted 0.61, as officials plan a third tranche of economic aid. AUD/USD meandered near session highs and around the 0.6100 handle following the announcement. EUR/USD and GBP/USD benefitted from the DXY’s pullback towards 99.000, with the pairs having stabilised around 1.1050 and 1.2250 respectively heading into the European open.

COMMODITIES

After settling lower on Thursday, crude futures were up in Asia trade, although it has generally respected the week's range. Concerns on the demand-side of the crude equation kept oil defensive on Thursday, while concerns of rising supply are also playing a role, amid the Russia/Saudi price war. WTI underperformed its Brent counterpart, with analysts suggesting it was a result of US refiners cutting back refinery runs amid falling consumption of products. Additionally, the US coronavirus relief bill had not set aside funds for the Energy Department to "fill up the SPR", as per President Trump's wishes; the DOE itself said it had funds for potential oil purchases for the SPR, and was working with Congress on the details. Meanwhile, a letter emerged revealing US lawmakers had urged Secretary of State Pompeo to call on ally Saudi Arabia to change its course on oil prices, which is threatening the US economy. Pompeo should encourage both Riyadh and Moscow to stop wreaking havoc in global markets—particularly as the US seeks to address a growing pandemic and avert an economic crisis. The lawmakers called on Saudi Arabia to partner with the United States on strategic energy infrastructure projects across the Indo-Pacific region and in the Americas. If the Saudis turned down US offers, the lawmakers called for various types of aid and assistance to be pulled. Elsewhere, Saudi-led coalition said it intercepted and destroyed missiles fired by Yemeni Houthis, according to Saudi state new. Meanwhile, spot gold was uneventful just above 1600/oz and failed to gain impetus from the weakening Buck.

US Senators wrote a letter persuading Saudi to leave OPEC, threatening sanctions, as posted by EnergyIntel. (Twitter) US Department of Energy said it has funds for potential oil purchases for the SPR and is working with Congress on details. (Newswires)

IEA's Chief Birol said the global oil storage capacity may be full very soon; oil demand recovery will not be easy or quick. (Newswires)

Libya's NOC says oil production stands at 96k BPD as of March 25th (vs. 114.31k BPD on March 8th). (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

Saudi-led coalition said it intercepted and destroyed missiles fired by Yemeni Houthis, according to Saudi state news. (Newswires)

US

The Tplex bull steepened as front-end Bills continued to decline into negative territory. The Fed’s monetary bazooka continues to alleviate funding pressures as O/N collateral rates remained low and minimal take-up in the repo operations, while demand in the reverse repo op continues to balloon - the negative yields in Bills are supporting Dealers’ move to park cash at the Fed. The negative front-end is also likely pushing participants further out the curve in search of yield. Elsewhere, the Treasury’s 7-year note auction was well-received, stopping through the 0.707% WI by 2.7bps, covered 2.76x (more than the six-auction average of 2.45x), and consistent with other recent auctions, dealers continue to take more than usual. By settlement, 2s10s +0.5bps at 54bps; 2-year -5bps at 0.281% and 10-year -3bps at 0.827%. T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 12+ TICKS HIGHER AT 137-23+.

Fed Chair Powell reiterated at FSOC the Fed is committed to using all tools to safeguard the economy; have taken an aggressive series of actions. (Newswires)

US banks had USD 50.8bln of outstanding loans via the discount window, as of Wednesday (vs USD 28.2bln last week), according to Fed data. (Newswires)

Fitch affirmed United States at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable. (Newswires)

APAC MACRO WRAP: Stocks move higher, dollar lower; RBI emergency cut
content:
* ASIA MARKET WRAP: The week is closing out on a quiet note in Asia, with little by way of fresh news flow to change recent narratives. Asian bourses started off on the front foot, taking their lead from a third consecutive day of gains on Wall Street, though some regions struggled to sustain gains. US equity futures re-opened mixed, but have ultimately gave up gains, and is languishing as the Europeans arrive. The dollar continued to ease, amid more favourable funding conditions and weak labour market data Thursday. The dollar's downside gave impetus to the JPY which fell through a long-term fib level around 108.60. Quiet, mildly risk on conditions also helped the Aussie to gain for a sixth session, taking it above the 50% retracement level of the March decline. Treasury trade was largely horizontal, with 10-year yields straddling 0.80%. Data did little to move the dial; China industrial profits contracted by the most on record (-38.3% Y/Y - markets had always expected a grim outcome), while Tokyo CPI was in line with expectations. Ahead, the focus will be on Capitol Hill, where the US House is expected to (eventually) advance the coronavirus relief bill.

* EQUITIES: Major APAC indices initially took their cues from Wall Street, rising firmly at the open, amid optimism that policymakers will continue to roll-out stimulus measures to guard economies against covid-induced downside. However, as the European day comes into focus, the picture is mixed, with Aussie shares now negative, and other bourses off highs. US indices finished up around 6%, with the Dow seeing its strongest three day run since 1931 and re-entering a bull-market, while the S&P had its best three-day performance since 1933. Gains were led by defensive sectors (utilities, telecoms, health care). Equities shrugged-off the highest weekly jobless claims print on record. Airlines rose as they stand to benefit from the government's virus relief package, which was the most cited reason for gains on Thursday. Some desks also noted that month/quarter-end rebalancing will see 850bln of flows into equities. US equity futures opened firmer, though have subsequently given up gains, and are trading over 1% in the red. Spread bettors are calling

* FX: The DXY edged further lower in Asia trade, having relinquished the 100.00 level in US hours, amid record high jobless claims. Policymaker support has added dollars into the system, and accordingly cross currency basis has eased, which has seen the yen continue to advance despite a constructive risk environment, where stocks are higher. Risk sensitive FX is higher, accordingly (AUD, NZD, CAD, GBP); particularly the Aussie, which vaulted 0.61, as officials plan a third tranche of economic aid. 

* CRUDE: After settling lower on Thursday, crude futures are up in Asia trade, although it has generally respected the week's range. Concerns on the demand-side of the crude equation kept oil defensive on Thursday, while concerns of rising supply are also playing a role, amid the Russia/Saudi price war. WTI underperformed its Brent counterpart, with analysts suggesting it was a result of US refiners cutting back refinery runs amid falling consumption of products. Additionally, the US coronavirus relief bill had not set aside funds for the Energy Department to "fill up the SPR", as per President Trump's wishes; the DOE itself said it had funds for potential oil purchases for the SPR, and was working with Congress on the details. Meanwhile, a letter emerged revealing US lawmakers had urged Secretary of State Pompeo to call on ally Saudi Arabia to change its course on oil prices, which is threatening the US economy. Pompeo should encourage both Riyadh and Moscow to stop wreaking havoc in global markets—particularly as the US seeks to address a growing pandemic and avert an economic crisis. The lawmakers called on Saudi Arabia to partner with the United States on strategic energy infrastructure projects across the Indo-Pacific region and in the Americas. If the Saudis turned down US offers, the lawmakers called for various types of aid and assistance to be pulled. Elsewhere, Saudi-led coalition says it intercepted and destroyed missiles fired by Yemeni Houthis, according to Saudi state news.

* G20: France President Macron says he and US President Trump were preparing "a strong new initiative" with other nations, which will be unveiled in the coming days. Earlier, reports had suggested that G20 leaders are to inject USD 5trln into the global economy to combat covid; leaders have committed to do 'whatever it takes' to overcome the pandemic, pledging to implement and fund all health measures necessary. Analysts also noted that the tone of language on trade was softer than recent statements, though stopped short of calling for an end to export bans on medical supplies. Elsewhere, US President Trump said it looks like the US can do another trade deal with China, though it will have to wait until after the Presidential election. Separately, US President Trump and China President Xi were said to have held a phone call overnight; details are yet to emerge.

* US FISCAL ACTION: The House has set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials. The Bill may not be able to pass via voice vote, and it was unclear on the timings of the next step, like a roll-call vote, the House Majority Leader's office said. Democrats may ask for a recorded vote, which may delay the passing of the bill. Analysts generally expect the Bill will (eventually) pass. Elsewhere, a bipartisan group of US lawmakers have urged the Trump administration to defer all tariffs during the covid pandemic, for at least a 90-day period, or until the crisis has passed.

* CORONAVIRUS CASES: The CDC Thursday reported the COVID-19 case count in the US was up to 68,440 from 54,453 on Wednesday, and deaths had risen to 994 from 737; however, a Reuters calculation suggests that cases are currently around 81,378, which would be above China and Italy's numbers. US President Trump said he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing. Mainland China reported 55 new virus cases (vs 67 on Thursday); the total case count  rose to 81,340 as of end-26th March; 5 new deaths were reported in the period (vs 6 on Thursday). No new cases were reported in the  Hubei province (total 67,801), though 5 new deaths reported (total 3,174).

* EUROPEAN MEASURES: European leaders were unable to agree on a strategy to drag their economies through the virus crisis. Italy reportedly rejected a draft prepared by aides, and urged leaders to come up with more solutions. Italy said leaders have 10 days to find an adequate solution to the emergency, and have tasked finance ministers to work out details of ESM credit lines; while nations like Spain and Italy have called for the creation of a joint-debt instrument, nations like Austria, Netherlands and Finland have leaned against those calls.

* SINGAPORE: Officials unveiled a SGD 48bln stimulus package, which will add to February’s SGD 6.4bln budget. Taken together, Singapore’s fiscal response to the economy slipping into recession amounts to a sizable 11% of GDP, UOB's analysts noted; the Monetary Authority of Singapore will announce its policy decision on Monday, and loosening of policy is virtually a foregone conclusion given that the country is heading into recession, UOB argues.

* RBI: RBI Governor Das confirmed the MPC held an emergency meeting this week, where it voted 4-2 to cut its main rate by 75bps to 4.40%; the reverse repo rate was cut to 4.15%. Governor Das said the move was designed to mitigate effects of the virus, revive growth and preserve financial stability. He added that the RBI's response must involve conventional and unconventional measures. Das noted that inflation was running higher than projections in January and February, and that aggregate demand may weaken, and ease inflation further due to Covid-19. Das also said projections for growth and inflation will be dependent on how Covid progresses; he noted that uncertainties in the outlook, and explained that is why the MPC has refrained from providing growth and inflation forecasts. Das also announced targeted long-term repo operations, offering up to INR 1trln.

* UK STIMULUS: Chancellor Sunak announced measures aimed at reassuring self-employed Britons, and will pay 80% of average monthly trading profit over the last three years, capped at GBP 2.5k/month.

* FITCH AFFIRMS US: Fitch Ratings affirmed the US at 'AAA', outlook stable. Ratings are supported by structural strengths. Fitch considers US debt tolerance to be higher than that of other 'AAA' sovereigns, though noted that high fiscal deficits and debt were starting to erode credit strengths. Fitch warned that the risk of a near-term negative rating action had risen given the magnitude of the shock to the economy and public finances from the coronavirus and the commensurate and necessary fiscal policy response, particularly in the absence of a credible consolidation plan for the country's pre-existing government debt challenges. Fitch believes the US economy will shrink by around 3% in 2020 (although this could be subject to further revision). In the event of the virus being contained during 2H20, Fitch assumes that real GDP growth will recover strongly in 2021.

He added that the RBI's response must involve conventional and unconventional measures. Das noted that inflation was running higher than projections in January and February, and that aggregate demand may weaken, and ease inflation further due to Covid-19. Das also said projections for growth and inflation will be dependent on how Covid progresses; he noted that uncertainties in the outlook, and explained that is why the MPC has refrained from providing growth and inflation forecasts. Das also announced targetted long-term repo operations, offering up to INR 1trln.

subject: RBI cuts rates by 75bps to 4.4%; voted 4-2 to cut rates; reverse repo rate lowered to 4.15%

• RBI Governor says move is designed to mitigate effects of the virus, revive growth and preserve financial stability.
  • Governor says response must involve conventional and unconventional measures
