APAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia equities open higher, US stock futures ease; DXY horizontal, JPY continues its advance
content:
* EQUITIES: Major APAC indicies took their cues from Wall Street, rising firmly at the open, and on course for their best week in nine years, amid optimism that policymakers will continue to roll-out stimulus measures to guard economies against covid-induced downside. US indices finished up around 6%, with the Dow seeing its strongest three day run since 1931 and re-entering a bull-market, while the S&P had its best three-day performance since 1933. Gains were led by defensive sectors (utilities, telecoms, health care). Equities shrugged-off the highest weekly jobless claims print on record. Airlines rose as they stand to benefit from the government's virus relief package, which was the most cited reason for gains on Thursday. Some desks also noted that month/quarter-end rebalancing will see 850bln flow into equities. US equity futures opened firmer, and after a slight wobble, continued their march higher, but have subsequently given up gains in recent trade, and the ES (M20) now trades with losses above 1%.

* FX: The DXY is starting the Asia day horizontally, having relinquished the 100.00 level in US trade, amid record high jobless claims. Policymaker support has added dollars into the system, and accordingly cross currency basis has eased, which has seen the JPY continue to advance despite a constructive risk environment, where stocks are higher. Risk sensitive FX is firmer accordingly (AUD, NZD, CAD, GBP). PBOC fixed the yuan midpoint at 7.0427 (prev. 7.0692); earlier, models had suggested 7.035-7.04, and skipped OMOs.

* US VIRUS CASES: The CDC Thursday reported the COVID-19 case count in the US was up to 68,440 from 54,453 on Wednesday, and deaths had risen to 994 from 737; however, a Reuters calculation suggests that cases are currently around 81,378, which would be above China and Italy's numbers. US President Trump said he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing

* CHINA VIRUS CASES: China mainland reports 55 new virus cases (vs 67 on Thursday); total case count  81,340 as of end-26th March; 5 new deaths in the period (vs 6 reported on Thursday). No new cases were reported in the  Hubei province (total 67,801), though 5 new deaths reported (total 3,174). To help stem the flow of the virus, China earlier announced it was banning entry by almost all foreigners. Outlets reported that Beijing had halted most international flights, and blocked even foreigners with Chinese residency or visas from entering.

* HOUSE VOTE: The House has set a two-hour debate on coronavirus relief bill on Friday 0900 ET/1300 GMT, according to House officials. The Bill may not be able to pass via voice vote, and it was unclear on the timings of the next step, like a roll-call vote, the House Majority Leader's office said. Democrats may ask for a recorded vote, which may delay the passing of the bill. Analysts generally expect the Bill will (eventually) pass.

* G20: France President Macron says he and US President Trump were preparing "a strong new initiative" with other nations, which will be unveiled in the coming days. Earlier, reports had suggested that G20 leaders are to inject USD 5trln into the global economy to combat covid; leaders have committed to do 'whatever it takes' to overcome the pandemic, pledging to implement and fund all health measures necessary. Analysts also noted that the tone of language on trade was softer than recent statements, though stopped short of calling for an end to export bans on medical supplies. Elsewhere, US President Trump said it looks like the US can do another trade deal with China, though it will have to wait until after the Presidential election.

* CHIP NAMES (TSM, AMAT, LRCX, KLAC) - US is moving forward with plans to limit chips to Huawei, according to sources cited by the WSJ. The proposal would require export licenses for many of the chips that are sold to Huawei that are made by US manufacturers; under the proposals, Commerce Dept could block sales of semis to TSMC. The measures would disadvantage US companies that produce semi equipment used by TSMC (could include AMAT, LRCX and KLAC). The rule will need writing, which could take weeks, sources said.
